setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
The function determines how to save the value of the
multiselect attribute
.
Syntax
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
(obj, ident, booleanValue)
Setting
Purpose
obj
An object with a multiselect attribute.
ident
An identifier of the multiselect attribute.
The parameter can be passed as text
attribute
, text
variable
, or
text
.
booleanValue
A logical parameter that determines whether to save the value in the multiselect attribute. If:
false
, objects will be added to or removed from the attribute’s value while considering objects previously saved in the database;
true
, the value of the attribute stored in the database will be overwritten - the current list of added objects will be set as the attribute’s value. Objects previously saved in the database will be removed.
By default, the value is set to false.
Note
Adding the function is done through manual input.
To save the attribute value in the database, use the
save
function.
Examples
Example 1
For instance, a list of employees eligible for a bonus is gradually formed based on sales performance. As employees meet sales targets, they are added to the "Bonuses" attribute along with previously added employees.
In this case, the method of saving the value of the
multiselect attribute
is determined by the
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
function using the following parameters:
For the current object, the
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
function sets the saving sign with
false
value for the "Bonuses" attribute with the "BONUSES_ID" identifier.
Setting the
false
value for the "booleanValue" parameter of the
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
function is advisable only if it was previously intentionally changed to
true
; otherwise, such a need is unnecessary as the default value is
false
.
Other functions used to write this algorithm.
Using a
loop
over the collection of
objects
of "Employees" type, the
condition
is checked for each employee’s sales performance (the "Sales" attribute added using
attrByVar
is compared with the "Sales target" attribute added through
attr
).
If an employee meets the sales target, he is added to the value of the "Bonuses" attribute using the
attr
function with the "Set value" option.
To save the value of the "Bonuses" attribute in the database, use the
save
function.
As a result of executing the algorithm, the "Bonuses" attribute will contain a list of outstanding employees as sales targets are achieved:
Example 2
Imagine, the Employee of the Month is determined by the highest sales volume. Since multiple employees may have the same sales volume, a list may be formed that needs to be recorded in the "Hall of Fame "
multiselect attribute
.
This list is updated monthly with new data, while the previous data is removed.
When the attribute value needs to be overwritten by the added objects, use the
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
function with the following parameters:
To ensure that the attribute values are overwritten when the algorithm is called, for the current object, the "Hall of Fame" attribute with the "BEST_EMPLOYEE_ID" identifier is set with the
setMultiSelectIsReplaceValues
function and the
true
value.
Other functions used to write this algorithm.
New variables are set using the
var
function.
A
loop
over the collection of
objects
of the "Employee" type is used to check for a
condition
to find the maximum sales volume (the "Sales" attribute of the "Employee" object inserted into the algorithm code using the
attrByVar
function).
Since only one value can be stored in the "Hall of Fame" attribute subsequently, a collection of "employeeList" objects needs to be created.
This collection, through a
loop
over the collection of
objects
of the "Employee" type, will be filled with employees with the maximum sales volume.
Once the value of the "Hall of Fame" attribute is set to the obtained collection of "employeeList" objects, use the
save
function to save it to the
current object
.
